chunks.original_text: 真君授以二词，师大悟，不觉下拜，自是日往亲炙。 以有老母，未即入道。 明年母捐馆，师乃弃家入昆箭山，礼真君於烟霞洞，求为弟子。 真君纳之，赐名璘，号恬然子，仍解纳衣去其袖而与之曰：勿患无袖，汝当自成。 盖传法之意也。 九年，宁海人有构金莲堂，以待真君挈其徒西归居之。 师携瓦罐乞食，误触之，碎。 真君别授一罐，题颂其上云：扑碎真灰罐，却得害风观。 直待悟残余，有个人人唤。 未几，师辞真君，去与王玉阳往居查山，真君亦赴汴京，马丹阳、谭长真、刘长生、邱长春四子实从。 十一年，师闻真君上仙，四子已入关，遂西游以访之。 十二年葬真君於祖庭，师欲与四子同庐墓侧，长真激之曰：随人脚跟转可乎？ 师明日遂行，至岐山，遇神人授今名字及道号。 十二年，度大庆关而束，翱翔赵魏问。 十五年，坐於沃州石桥之下，缄口不语，河水泛溢身不少移，水亦弗及。 人绩之食则食，无则已。 虽祁寒盛暑兀然无变，身槁木而心死灰，如是者六年。 昌邑君之季女嫁为真定郭长倩之夫人，长倩夫妇过沃州，知师在桥下，驻车拜谒，赠之衣物，所以存慰者甚厚，师藐然若不相识，一无所受。 夫人感泣，长倩嗟异而去。 二十二年，师过滦城，又与神人遇，受大易秘义，自尔为人言未来事不差毫发。 至镇阳居观，升堂演道，远近来听者常数百人。 已而阐化诸方，专以利物度人为务，由是郝太古之名闻天下。 明昌初，东还宁海。 一日欲作易图，遽索纸笔，适粥熟，弟子不即与，请俟食已。 师曰：速持来，我方得意，何暇食粥。 笔入手，布纸挥染，疾若风雨，不终朝，成三十三图，其旨意皆天人之蕴奥，昔贤所未发者。 咸平高士王贤佐，占筮素精，见师推服，尽弃其学而学焉。 由是技进，名动阙庭。 其他灵异之迹，如天长顶告侯子真之火，恩州夜入王镇国之梦者，尚多有之，不可婵纪。 春秋七十有三，以崇庆元年腊月晦日，仙蜕於州之先天观。 前此三年，劝其徒预营冢圹，告以死期，及是果然。 平生制作有三教入易论一卷，示教直言一卷，心经解一卷，救苦经解一卷，周易参同契简要释义、诗赋、杂文、乐府，及所作易图，号《太古集》凡十五卷行于世。 噫，道家者流其源出於老#7庄，后之人失其本旨，派而为方术，为符录，为烧炼，为章醮，派愈分而迷愈远，其来久矣。 迨乎金季，重阳真君不阶师友，一悟绝人，殆若天授。 起於终南，达於昆箭，招其同类而开导之、锻炼之，创立一家之教曰全真。 其修持大略以识心见性，除情去欲，忍耻含垢，苦己利人为之宗。 老氏所谓知其雄守其雌，知其白守其黑，知其荣守其辱，为道日损，损之又损以至无为。 庄生所谓游心於淡，合黑於漠，纯纯常常，乃比於狂，外天地，遗万物，探根宁极，才全而德不形者，全真有之，老庄之道於是乎始合。 重阳唱之，马谭刘邱王郝六子和之，天下之道流祖之，是谓七真，师其一也。 非天授之，其孰能与於此哉？ 师逝之后，弟子行绿四出，能世其业者甚众。 高弟范玄通与栖云王宗师，又其尤者。 当中原板荡，国朝隆兴之初，一居东平，一往来乎燕汴，建琳宇，开玄坛，聚徒讲说，贵贱钦仰，宗风大振，道价增崇，不臧太古。
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfected Lord bestowed upon him two verses, and the master experienced a great awakening, unconsciously bowing in reverence. From that day forth, he visited daily to receive direct instruction. Yet, as his aged mother still lived, he did not immediately enter the Dao. The following year, when his mother passed away, the master abandoned his home and journeyed to Mount Kunjian, where he paid homage to the Perfected Lord at the Misty Cloud Grotto and sought to become his disciple. The Perfected Lord accepted him, bestowing the name *Lin* and the sobriquet *Tranquil One*, then removed his own robe, tore off its sleeves, and gave it to him, saying: “Do not lament the lack of sleeves—you shall forge your own path.” This conveyed the intent of transmitting the Dharma.

In the ninth year, the people of Ninghai constructed the Golden Lotus Hall to await the Perfected Lord’s return, who would lead his disciples west to reside there. The master, carrying an earthen jar, begged for alms when he accidentally shattered it. The Perfected Lord presented him with another jar, inscribing a verse upon it:

*Shattered the true ash jar,*
*Yet gained the Wind-Harmonizing Abbey.*
*Only when the remnants are realized,*
*Will someone call you by name.*

Shortly after, the master took leave of the Perfected Lord and departed with Wang Yuyang to dwell on Mount Cha. The Perfected Lord then journeyed to Bianjing, accompanied by Ma Danyang, Tan Changzhen, Liu Changsheng, and Qiu Changchun. In the eleventh year, learning that the Perfected Lord had ascended to immortality and the Four Disciples had entered Guanzhong, the master traveled west in search of them. In the twelfth year, he interred the Perfected Lord at the ancestral sanctuary and wished to join the Four Disciples in guarding the tomb. Changzhen admonished him, saying: “Can you merely follow in others’ footsteps?” The next day, the master departed and, upon reaching Mount Qi, encountered a divine being who bestowed upon him his present name and Daoist title.

In the twelfth year, he crossed the Great Celebration Pass and journeyed east, soaring through the lands of Zhao and Wei. In the fifteenth year, he sat beneath the Stone Bridge of Wozhou, sealing his lips in silence. Though the river swelled and overflowed, he did not stir, and the waters did not reach him. If people offered food, he ate; if not, he remained unmoved. Through bitter cold and scorching heat, he sat motionless, his body like withered wood and his heart like dead ashes—thus for six years. The youngest daughter of the Lord of Changyi, married to Guo Changqian of Zhen Ding, passed through Wozhou with her husband. Learning of the master beneath the bridge, they halted their carriage to pay homage and presented him with clothing and provisions, offering abundant comfort. The master, however, regarded them with indifference, as if they were strangers, and accepted nothing. The lady wept in sorrow, and Guo Changqian sighed in wonder as they departed.

In the twenty-second year, the master passed through Luancheng and again encountered a divine being, from whom he received the secret meanings of the *Great Changes*. Thereafter, his predictions of future events were never off by even a hair’s breadth. Upon arriving at Zhenyang, he ascended the hall of a Daoist abbey to expound the Dao, drawing hundreds of listeners from near and far. Thereafter, he propagated the teachings across the land, dedicating himself to benefiting beings and guiding others. Thus, the name of Hao Taigu resounded throughout the realm.

At the beginning of the Mingchang era, he returned east to Ninghai. One day, wishing to create a diagram of the *Changes*, he abruptly demanded brush and paper. As his porridge was just ready, his disciples hesitated, suggesting he eat first. The master replied: “Bring them at once! I am in the midst of inspiration—how can I wait for porridge?” Taking up the brush, he spread the paper and brushed the diagrams with the speed of wind and rain. By mid-morning, he had completed thirty-three charts, their meanings encompassing the profound mysteries of heaven and humanity, uncharted by former sages. Wang Xianzuo of Xianping, a scholar skilled in divination, upon seeing the master’s work, revered him deeply, abandoning his own studies to learn from him. Through this, his arts advanced, and his fame reached the imperial court. Other wondrous deeds—such as foretelling the fire at Tianchang Peak to Hou Zizhen or appearing in the dreams of Wang Zhenguo of Enzhou—were too numerous to record.

At the age of seventy-three, on the last day of the twelfth lunar month in the first year of the Chongqing era, he shed his mortal form at the Primordial Abbey of Ninghai. Three years prior, he had urged his disciples to prepare his tomb, foretelling the date of his death, which came to pass as predicted. His lifetime works included *On the Three Teachings Entering the Changes* (1 juan), *Direct Words on Instruction* (1 juan), *Commentary on the Heart Sutra* (1 juan), *Commentary on the Sutra of Salvation from Suffering* (1 juan), *Essential Exegesis of the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*, as well as poems, rhapsodies, miscellaneous writings, and ballads, along with the *Changes* diagrams he had created. These were compiled into *The Taigu Collection* (15 juan), which circulated in the world.

Alas! The Daoist tradition traces its origins to Laozi and Zhuangzi. Yet later generations lost its original intent, branching into techniques, talismans, alchemy, and ritual invocations. The more the schools divided, the further they strayed—this has been the case for ages. By the late Jin dynasty, the Perfected Lord Chongyang, without relying on teachers or friends, attained a sudden awakening beyond ordinary men, as if by heavenly decree. Rising in Zhongnan and reaching Kunjian, he gathered like-minded souls, instructing and refining them, and founded a school called Quanzhen. Its practice broadly emphasized recognizing the mind and seeing one’s nature, eliminating passions and desires, enduring shame and embracing disgrace, and suffering for oneself while benefiting others as its core principles. This aligned with Laozi’s words: “Know the masculine, keep to the feminine; know the white, keep to the black; know the honorable, keep to the humble,” and “Reduce and further reduce, until you reach non-action.” It also echoed Zhuangzi’s: “Let the mind wander in simplicity, merge with the vastness; be pure and constant, like one who is mad; transcend heaven and earth, forget all things; probe the root and rest in the ultimate—where power is complete yet virtue does not manifest.” Quanzhen embodied these teachings, reuniting the Dao of Laozi and Zhuangzi.

Chongyang initiated it, and the Six Disciples—Ma, Tan, Liu, Qiu, Wang, and Hao—harmonized with him. The Daoist lineages of the world traced their origins to them, known as the Seven Perfected. Who but those divinely endowed could partake in this? After the master’s passing, his disciples spread far and wide, and many carried on his legacy. Among his foremost disciples, Fan Xuantong and Wang Zongshi of Cloud Abode were the most eminent. During the turmoil of the Central Plains and the early years of the imperial Longxing era, one resided in Dongping, while the other traveled between Yan and Bian, establishing abbeys, opening altars, gathering disciples, and expounding the teachings. Revered by high and low alike, the school’s influence flourished, and its prestige soared—all thanks to Taigu.

Observing the master’s uncommon bearing and recognizing his immortal potential, he sought a means to awaken him. Turning his back to the shop, he said: “Why do you not turn back?” The master was startled and found his words extraordinary. When the Perfected Lord departed, the master closed his shop and followed him. Upon reaching his lodging, he sought instruction.

chunks.original_text: 今洞阳耆艾敦厉，刚毅木讷，食师之德，干父之蛊，当释道纷争，摧败挫钮之际，寂然湛然，守之以谦冲，安之以委顺，处之以镇静，操修无方，精进不辍，用能上取圣知，特隆玺书褒美。 较其难易，又不出於栖云之下，谓非太古之泽，将何归乎？ 凡今之人欲知太古，请观其子，欲知其子，请观其孙。 铭曰： 东方云海空复空，群仙出没空明中，此语常怪东坡公，神仙有则八表同。 不应秀止东方钟，昆箭山高天比崇，左顾右瞰搏桑宫，上有一洞烟霞封。 重阳发之麾鬼工，紫黑直与问浮通，马谭刘邱王郝从，六子娇矫皆人雄。 缥缈至自蓬莱峰，惊见碧海磨青铜，煌煌七朵金芙蓉，信哉仙人出於东。 就中郝公鸾凤龙，洗心以易虚玲珑，藏用於密退以冲，枇糠富贵不挂胸。 刚央物莫婴其锋，训练复遇王元戎，纳衣一传神契融，有袖无袖由人缝。 同门之朋桂与种，脚跟不必随渠侬，沃州石桥张果踪，旦如虹蜕插苍穹。 大道在此南北冲，何须远走巢云松，止而不动吾非慵，艮乃万物之始终。 结踟趺坐为疮聋，朝观日出光咙瞳，吞霞入腹丹火红，暮观流波朝彼宗。 河车挽水玄霜蓬，有人问之趋下风，如以寸庄撞巨锺，摇手使去妨吾功。 过桥行人抗尘容，僵名仆利不有躬，见公视世犹蚁蜂，形骸土木心冥鸿。 颗必有沘羞顽庸，反求於身当发蒙，撙贪节爱廖痕恫，憧憧往来秋夏冬。 百感一二亦已丰，如此利益谁能穷，确乎六年真苦攻，养成诧女连婴童。 奋袖起舞知德充，愿以所余及倥恫，普度一切超樊笼，泥在钧兮金在镕。 螟蛉螺赢无常虫，功成朝元去忽忽，飞霞佩玉呜冬隆，云装烟驾沧淇重。 弱水万里昏蒙蒙，淮南小山空桂丛，黄芽欲种须圃农，公不可见忧心冲， 栖云老仙亦难逢，住世赖有徐神翕。 七真赞 北平王粹子正述
chunks.translated_text:
In the present day, the elders of Dongyang remain steadfast in their exhortations—unyielding, resolute, and plainspoken—nourished by their master’s virtue, rectifying what their forebears had left undone. Amid the tumult of Daoist and Buddhist strife, when all was in disarray and resistance seemed futile, they remained serene and composed, upholding humility, embracing submission, and abiding in tranquility. Their cultivation knew no fixed method, yet their progress never ceased. Thus, they attained sagely wisdom from above and were honored with imperial decrees of praise. In comparing the ease or difficulty of their path, they did not fall short of Xiyun. If not for the legacy of Taigu, to whom else could such merit be ascribed?

Those who now seek to know Taigu should observe his disciples; those who seek to know his disciples should observe their successors.

**Inscription:**
The eastern clouds and seas stretch empty, again empty,
Immortals emerge and vanish in the radiant void.
I have long marveled at Dongpo’s words—
For if immortals exist, the Eight Directions share the same truth.

Yet why should excellence be confined to the eastern bell?
Kun and Jian mountains rise, rivaling heaven’s height.
Gazing left and right, they embrace Fusang’s palace,
Where a single grotto lies sealed in mist and rosy clouds.

Hongyang summoned them, commanding ghostly craftsmen,
Purple and black threads weaving through the floating world.
Ma, Tan, Liu, Qiu, Wang, and Hao followed—
Six stalwart heroes, each a dragon among men.

From Penglai’s peaks they came, ethereal and remote,
Startled to see the azure sea polished like bronze.
Behold! Seven golden lotuses, resplendent—
Truly, immortals arise from the East.

Among them, Master Hao, phoenix and dragon,
Purified his heart to attain emptiness and clarity.
His actions hidden, his retreat marked by modesty,
He cast off wealth and rank like chaff, unburdening his breast.

His firmness deterred all who might test his edge.
Trained anew, he encountered General Wang,
And in a single transmission of patched robes, their spirits merged.
Whether clad in sleeves or not, let each sew as they please.

Among his fellow disciples, Gui and Zhong,
Need not follow others’ paths.
Like Zhang Guo’s traces at Wolzhou’s stone bridge,
Or the morning rainbow’s molt piercing the azure vault.

The Great Dao resides at this northern and southern crossroads—
Why seek distant pines in clouded peaks?
To halt is not laziness,
For *gen* marks the beginning and end of all things.

Seated in lotus, he mended deafness and blindness,
At dawn, gazing at the sun’s rising light, his eyes brightened.
Swallowing mist, his belly glowed with cinnabar fire;
At dusk, he observed the flowing waves, facing their source.

The river chariot drew water, the frost-laden fleabane turned,
When questioned, he bowed low.
As if striking a great bell with a tiny mallet,
He waved them away, lest they disrupt his work.

Passersby on the bridge bore the dust of the world,
Chasing fame and profit, losing themselves.
To him, the world’s people were but ants and bees—
His form was earth and wood, his heart as vast as the wild goose’s flight.

Those who cling to trivial gains, ashamed of their dullness,
Should turn inward to awaken.
Curb greed, temper desire, and cast off sorrow—
Through ceaseless toil, seasons turn from autumn to winter.

A hundred feelings, even a fraction, are enough.
Such benefits—who could exhaust them?
Steadfast for six years, truly arduous cultivation,
Nurtured the wondrous maiden and linked infants.

Sleeves raised in dance, knowing virtue’s fullness,
He wished to extend his surplus to the suffering.
To universally deliver all, transcending cages,
Like clay on the potter’s wheel or gold in the crucible.

Grubs and snails, no fixed form—
Once the work was complete, he departed in an instant.
Soaring on flying rosy clouds, jade pendants chiming,
His cloud-borne chariot and misty steed weighed heavy on the azure waves.

Weak waters stretch ten thousand miles, dim and boundless,
Huainan’s Xiao Mountain, its osmanthus groves now empty.
To plant the yellow sprout requires a gardener’s care—
Yet the master cannot be seen, my heart heavy with longing.

Even the old immortal of Xiyun is hard to meet,
But the world is sustained by Xu Shenxi.

**Eulogy to the Seven Perfected**
Composed by Wang Cuizi of Beiping

chunks.original_text: 重阳王真人 出应道运，豪雄绝伦。 甘河得遇，兀若狂人。 挈还四师，大开全真。 巍巍法教，东海西秦。 丹阳马真人 晚契奇因，尽舍家赀。 千朝得道，三髻承师。 风雷示化，金玉垂辞。 邈矣前躅，如何可追。 长真谭真人 一见师真，症疾顿愈。 央烈入道，水云为倡。 归衬终南，聚徒洛土。 教风既弘，蜕然高举。 长生刘真人 童真之力，圣贤所扶。 风姿秀异，洛市工夫。 中遭厄郁，所守不渝。 声名卒显，被召海隅。 长春邱真人 猜欤长者，不可复得。 三朝推尊，才学功德。 愍此兵戈，远涉西北。 九九乃终，世人莫测。 玉阳王真人 幼遇玄庭，再礼重阳。 飞伞送号，金莲共芳。 迹多神异，名动帝王。 高山景行，千载云光。 广宁郝真人 虽出阀阅，独喜林泉。 两词一纳，终始师传。 神示易秘，沃桥六年。 化绿逆顺，悉合自然。 甘水仙源录卷之二竟 ＃1原文漏『垠』字，据艺风堂拓本补足。 ＃2『锺离』后漏『真人』两字，今据柳风堂石墨拓本补足。 ＃3『有妇人者一，余六真』，柳风堂石墨拓本无此句。 ＃4柳风堂石墨拓本此句为：『真君并六真既各有传』。 ＃5柳风堂石墨拓本此句为：『盖有传应大法师张守真受斓圣真君至一司以彰宋朝』。 ＃6『他门』，柳风堂石墨拓本作『玄门』。 ＃7『老一原作『若』，据文义改。 甘水仙源录卷之三 夷门天乐道人李道谦集

**The Seven Perfected**

**Wang Zhenren of Chongyang**
Emerging in response to the Dao’s turning, peerless in heroism.
At Gan River, his encounter left him dazed, like a madman.
He gathered the Four Masters, grandly inaugurating the Complete Perfection.
Majestic the teachings—spanning the Eastern Sea and Western Qin.

**Ma Zhenren of Danyang**
Late to awaken to his extraordinary cause, he relinquished all family wealth.
After a thousand mornings of cultivation, he received the Three Topknots from his master.
Wind and thunder heralded his transformation; gold and jade left his final words.
Distant his former footsteps—how could they be retraced?

**Tan Zhenren of Changzhen**
At first sight of the Perfected One, his chronic ailments vanished.
Fiercely he entered the Dao, with water and clouds as his companions.
Returning to settle in Zhongnan, he gathered disciples in Luo’s land.
Once the teaching’s wind had spread, he shed his form and ascended.

**Liu Zhenren of Changsheng**
The power of his youthful purity, upheld by sages and worthies.
His bearing refined and extraordinary, his labors in the Luo markets.
Though beset by hardship, his resolve never wavered.
His renown ultimately shone, and he was summoned to the sea’s edge.

**Qiu Zhenren of Changchun**
Ah, that elder—never to be found again.
Thrice honored by the court, for his talent, learning, and virtue.
Moved by the ravages of war, he journeyed far to the northwest.
At eighty-one, he passed—none could fathom his depth.

**Wang Zhenren of Yuyang**
In youth, he met the Mystic Court, twice paying homage to Chongyang.
A flying canopy bore his title; golden lotuses shared his fragrance.
His traces brimmed with divine marvels, his name stirred emperors.
A lofty mountain’s radiant path—his glory shines through the ages.

**Hao Zhenren of Guangning**
Though born of noble lineage, he alone cherished forests and springs.
Two poems, one robe—his devotion to the master never ceased.
Divine signs revealed the *Yi*’s secrets; six years at Wo Bridge.
Transforming adversity and fortune, all aligned with nature.

*Ganshui Xianyuan Lu, Scroll Two—End*
*Ganshui Xianyuan Lu, Scroll Three*
*Compiled by Li Daoqian, the Recluse of Yimen*

chunks.original_text: 清和妙道广化真人尹宗师碑铭并序 汝阳弋壳撰 宗师，全真嗣教六世祖也。 自守真绪，风化鼎盛，什百於畴昔。 形器之域，古今同尽，春秋八十有三，遽有拂衣启手之叹，以辛亥二月六日升于大房山清和宫之正寝。 宁神五华山者老，几十稔矣。 嗣教诚明张公一日语众曰：清和师思报祖师之恩，遂大葬之礼，仍即其福地，并建宫宇，胜盘甲天下，弘阐祖道，功越古今。 吾侪享其成业，今无一报，颜实腆矣。 将刻碑纪实，以诏无穷，若何？ 会日唯。 遂以中统三年十月吉日，征文於汝阳弋壳。 仆以师真道德高厚，奥妙无方，诅以荒疏．浅浅者所能窥测形容哉？ 固辞不可，谨按门人马志通所纪行状，仍摭其功德之着，见於耳目者，序述之。 夫道之在天下一而已，惟天之所以界#1付於圣贤者无不备，其所以济斯世而见於功用者，或久近广狭之不齐，何哉？ 曰：时也。 时非圣贤所能必，能不滞其时而已。 或拱揖廊庙，或私淑侧陋，或清静而化，揖让而治，或平水土，降播种，或放伐以救焚溺，或宽默以革苛伪。 文胜质丧，则示还纯反朴之训。 礼壤乐崩，则正三纲五常之教。 大则天下后世，小则一郡一邑，随机应变，与物推移，要不过乎徇道以济斯世耳。 由迹以观之，功用之不齐者，所遇之时异也。 则天之以是道而界付於圣贤者，曷尝有二哉？ 道犹水也，渴则为酌饮，旱则为灌溉。 道犹火也，饥则为烹饪，寒则为煦妪。 用虽不同，而水火曷尝有二哉？ 顷以金录讫运，丧乱并兴，黔黎珍於殖酝，玉石烬於烈火，天意开顾，挺生至人，全界斯道，以假援之之手，於是重阳而后，丹阳、长真、长生、长春继出，而全真之教兴。 及清和接长春之统，授受之际，累圣之妙无余蕴。 父作子述，阐化数十年，徒倡褊天下，闻望重朝野。 风之所靡，狠戾易心，强梗顺命，革烦苛为清静，化汤火为衽席，挈一世鄙夭之民，跻之仁寿之域。 自古教法之盛，功德之隆，惟清和师为最，盖天之界付之道一，而所遇之时异也。 师讳志平，字大和，姓尹氏。 远祖居沧州，前宋时有官莱州者，因家焉。 显高祖妣有子九人，俱登进士第，仕至郡守者七人。 显大父公直、显考弘谊，皆隐德不耀。 师於大定九年正月一一十日生，是夕其母方寐，见仪卫异常，皆盛服而入，神思愕然，惊寤，师已诞矣。 时里人相惊日，尹氏宅火。 奔救之，至则无火。 稍长举止异凡儿，三岁颖悟善记事，五岁入学日诵千余言，读书即玄解。 尝因祀事，究生死理，杳然遐想自忘。 七岁遇陕西王大师，有从游意。 十四岁遇丹阳真人，遽欲弃家入道，其父难之，潜往。 十九岁复迫令还家，锢之，竟逃出再三，始从之。 住昌邑县之西庵，常独坐树下达旦。 或一夕，见长生刘真人飘然而来，断其首，剖其心，复置之，觉而大有所悟。 后住庵福山县，养疾惠困，勤瘁者累年，众德之。 游潍州，时龙虎完颜氏素豪倨？ 慕师道德，施囿地，创观日玉清，率家人尊事之。 今观废於兵，而松桧郁为茂林。 后觐长春真人於栖霞观，执弟子礼，真人特器异之，付授无所隐。 又受易於太古郝真人，受口诀於玉阳王真人。 自是道业日隆，声价大振，四方学者翕然宗之。 己卯岁，太祖皇帝遣便宜刘仲禄，征长春真人。
chunks.translated_text:
**Epitaph and Preface for the Perfected Master Yin, the True Person of Vast Transformation through the Wondrous Dao of Clarity and Harmony**

Composed by Yi Ke of Ruyang

The Master was the sixth-generation patriarch of the Quanzhen lineage, inheriting the teachings of *Shouzhen*. Under his guidance, the transformative influence of the Dao flourished, surpassing the past tenfold. Yet the realm of form and vessel shares the same end in all ages. At eighty-three, he suddenly sighed at the prospect of casting off his robe and raising his hands in departure. On the sixth day of the second lunar month in the *xinhai* year, he ascended at the *Qinghe Palace* on Mount Dafang.

For nearly a decade, he had settled his spirit upon the Five-Flowered Mountain. One day, the enlightened *Zhang Gong*, who succeeded him in the teaching, addressed the assembly: "The Master of Clarity and Harmony sought to repay the debt of gratitude to his forebears. Thus, he performed the grand funeral rites and, at that blessed site, erected palaces and halls—unmatched in splendor beneath heaven—thereby magnifying the ancestral Dao. His merit surpasses all past and present. We who enjoy the fruits of his labor have yet to offer even the slightest repayment; our shame runs deep. We shall now inscribe a stele to record his deeds for endless generations. What say you?" The assembly unanimously assented.

In the third year of *Zhongtong*, on an auspicious day in the tenth lunar month, they commissioned *Yi Ke* of Ruyang to compose the text. I, though unworthy, dared not refuse, for the Master’s virtue and power were profound, his mysteries boundless—how could my crude and shallow words ever capture or depict them? Thus, I humbly followed the *Xingzhuang* recorded by his disciple *Ma Zhitong*, gathering the visible and witnessed manifestations of his merit and virtue to compose this account.

The Dao in the world is but one. Yet the endowments bestowed by Heaven upon the sagely and worthy are never lacking, though their manifestations in aiding this world—whether in duration, scope, or immediacy—vary. Why? The answer lies in the times. The times are not something even the sagely can command; they can only avoid being shackled by them. Some bow in the halls of state, others humbly instruct from secluded corners. Some transform through stillness, governing with deference; others pacify floods, sow seeds, or quell chaos to rescue the drowning. When culture overwhelms substance, they teach a return to purity and simplicity. When rites crumble and music collapses, they restore the teachings of the Three Bonds and Five Constants. Whether their influence spans the world and ages or is confined to a single commandery or village, they adapt to circumstances and shift with the times. Yet their aim remains the same: to follow the Dao and aid the world.

Viewed through their deeds, the disparities in their achievements arise from the differing eras they encountered. Yet the Dao bestowed by Heaven upon the sagely and worthy has never been twofold. The Dao is like water: when thirsty, it becomes a drink; in drought, it becomes irrigation. The Dao is like fire: when hungry, it cooks food; in cold, it warms the body. Though its uses differ, water and fire remain unchanged. Is the Dao any different?

In recent times, the Mandate of the Golden Register expired, and chaos erupted. The black-haired people were slaughtered like livestock, jade and stone alike burned in the flames. Heaven, in its compassion, raised forth a perfected one, entrusting him with the Dao to extend a hand of deliverance. After *Chongyang*, *Danyang*, *Changzhen*, *Changsheng*, and *Changchun* emerged in succession, and the Quanzhen teaching flourished. When *Qinghe* inherited the mantle from *Changchun*, the transmission between them held no hidden mysteries of the successive sages. Like a father’s work continued by his son, he propagated the teaching for decades. His disciples spread across the land, his reputation resounding in court and countryside alike. Where his influence reached, the fierce softened their hearts, the stubborn submitted, and the oppressive gave way to stillness. He turned raging fires into peaceful mats, lifting a generation of the coarse and short-lived into the realm of benevolence and longevity. In the grandeur of teachings and the magnitude of merit, none surpassed the Master of Clarity and Harmony. For the Dao bestowed by Heaven is one, yet the times he encountered were unique.

The Master’s personal name was *Zhiping*, his courtesy name *Dahe*, and his surname *Yin*. His distant ancestors hailed from Cangzhou. During the former Song, one held office in Laizhou and settled there. His illustrious great-great-grandmother bore nine sons, all of whom passed the imperial examinations and served as prefects—seven of them. His illustrious great-grandfather *Gongzhi* and his illustrious father *Hongyi* both concealed their virtue, never seeking renown.

The Master was born on the twenty-first day of the first lunar month in the ninth year of *Dading*. That night, his mother dreamed of an extraordinary procession, all in splendid attire, entering her chamber. Startled, she awoke to find the Master already born. The villagers rushed to their home, shouting, "The Yin residence is on fire!" But upon arrival, no flames were found.

As he grew, his bearing surpassed that of ordinary children. At three, he was precocious and quick to remember; at five, he entered school, reciting over a thousand words daily, grasping the profound meaning of his readings. Once, while observing ancestral rites, he pondered the principles of life and death, lost in distant contemplation. At seven, he encountered Master *Wang* of Shaanxi and felt drawn to follow him. At fourteen, he met the Perfected *Danyang* and immediately wished to abandon his home for the Dao, but his father resisted. He fled in secret. At nineteen, his family forced him to return, confining him, yet he escaped repeatedly until they finally relented.

He resided at the Western Hermitage in Changyi County, often sitting alone beneath a tree until dawn. One evening, he saw the Perfected *Changsheng Liu* arrive like a drifting cloud. The Perfected severed his head, split open his heart, and replaced them. Awakening, he gained profound insight.

Later, he dwelled at a hermitage in Fushan County, tending to the sick and aiding the distressed for years, earning the reverence of all. Traveling to Weizhou, the dragon-and-tiger clan of the *Wanyan* family, once proud and aloof, admired his virtue. They donated garden land to build the *Yuqing* Abbey, where the entire household honored him. Though the abbey was later destroyed in war, its pines and cypresses flourished into a dense forest.

Later, he paid homage to the Perfected *Changchun* at the *Qixia* Abbey, bowing as a disciple. The Perfected held him in special regard, transmitting all without reservation. He also received the *Yi* from the Perfected *Hao* of *Taigu* and oral instructions from the Perfected *Yuyang Wang*. From then on, his Daoist practice advanced daily, his reputation soaring. Scholars from all directions flocked to him as their master.

In the *jimao* year, the *Taizu Emperor* dispatched *Liu Zhonglu*, acting on imperial authority, to summon the Perfected *Changchun*...

chunks.original_text: 仲禄及益都，真常李公曰：长春今在海上，非先见尹公，必不能成此盛事。 及潍阳，谒师於玉清之丈室，见其神采严重，不觉畏敬自失，从容语及诏旨，师大喜曰：将以斯道觉斯民，今其时矣。 遂偕往觐长春真人於莱州昊天观。 先是金宋聘命交至，皆不应，至是师劝行，次计北上。 时从者十八人，皆德望素重者，师为之冠。 辛巳及癸未，备尝难阻，既见帝於西印度，奏对称旨。 还及云中，真人闻山束乱，国兵又南下，曰：彼方生灵，命悬砧鼎，非汝莫能救。 遂遣往招慰，闻者乐附，所全活甚多。 乙酉岁，劝令长春真人住太极宫，即今长春宫也。 师在席下，四方尊礼者云合，师曰：我无功德，敢与享此供奉乎。 遂辞退住德兴之龙阳观。 屡承真人手割示以托重意。 及真人升，师方隐烟霞观，又欲绝迹远遁#2，为众以主教事敦请，勉从之。 还长春宫，以嗣事自任，自是徒众辐赓，辇烬乐贡者，日充塞庭宇。 忽谓众曰：吾素驮冗剧，喜山林。 遂因平乐请主醮事，而出遁景州，之束山。 未几，燕之僚士固请还宫。 壬辰，帝南征还，师迎见於顺天，慰问甚厚，仍令皇后代祀香於长春宫，肌责优渥。 甲午春，游母间山，太玄观之李虚玄语人曰：去年院中青气氤氲者累日，占者以为当有异人至。 今师来，既验矣。 瑜春南归，及玉田，众喜，为数日留。 日已哺，遽促驾兼夜行五十余里，舍丰草中，众莫知所以。 后还宫，始知在玉田时，有寇数百欲劫掠，追至大合甸，不及而反。 从者相贺曰：非师奈我辈何？ 时皇后遣使劳问，赐道经一藏。 乙未春，诣沁州，主黄录醮事。 入郊城境，居人或梦县之地祇曰：真人来，当警卫无虞。 及平遥理醮事，时旱久且风，醮之三昼夜，灯烛恬然，在他境犹风。 沁帅杜德康、平遥帅梁瑜各施宫观，一方倾心焉。 九月达平阳，分命披云宋公率众镂道藏经板，不数载而完，所费不赀，而人乐成之，亦师为之张本。 师以此道化大行，归功祖师重阳真人，遂留意祖庭。 时京兆行省田公驰疏来请，适与师意合，丙申春始达。 於榛莽中规度兆域，及宫观基址。 终南太华等处诸观宇，废不能复，咸请主於师。 时陕右甫定，遗民犹有保栅未下者，闻师至，相先归附，师为抚慰，皆按#3堵如故。 继而被命於云中，令师选天下戒行精严之士，为国祈福，化人作善。 时平逼之兴国观、惇之神清、前高之玉虚白云洞、定襄之重阳、给之神霄、平阳之玄都，皆主於师。 秋，帝命中书杨公召还燕，道经太行山问，群盗罗拜受教，悉为良民。 出井陉，历赵魏齐鲁，请命者皆谢遣，原野道路设香花，望尘迎拜者日千万计，贡物山积，略不顾。 戊戌春，忽曰：吾老矣，久厌劳事，以正月上日传衣钵於真常李公，俾主教事。 乃卜筑五华山，并增茸大房山之真阳观，更日清和宫，以为菟裘焉。 终南祖庭葬具已备，庚子冬请师董其成，欣然而往，虽冒寒跋险不惮也。 常日，吾以报师恩耳。 时季冬，京兆一境旱，众祷曰：师来和气必应，下车而雪。 大箴葬礼，以明年正月二十五日既事。 时陕右虽甫定，犹为边鄙重地，经理及会葬者，四方道俗云集常数万人，物议汹汹不安，赖师道德素重#4，镇伏邪，故得完其功。
chunks.translated_text:
When *Liu Zhonglu* arrived in *Yidu*, the Perfected *Changchang* Li said: "Master *Changchun* is now at sea. Without first meeting Master *Yin*, this grand affair cannot be accomplished." Upon reaching *Weiyang*, he paid his respects to the Master in the private chamber of *Yuqing* Abbey. Struck by the Master’s solemn and dignified bearing, *Zhonglu* unconsciously felt awe and reverence. When the imperial decree was calmly presented, the Master rejoiced greatly, saying: "To awaken the people with this Dao—now is the time!" Thereupon, they journeyed together to pay homage to the Perfected *Changchun* at the *Haotian* Abbey in *Laizhou*.

Previously, both the Jin and Song courts had repeatedly sent envoys with summons, all of which he declined. This time, at the Master’s urging, he agreed to set out, planning his route northward. His retinue numbered eighteen, all men of long-standing virtue and renown, with the Master at their head. From the *xinsi* year to the *guiwei* year, they endured countless hardships and obstacles. Upon meeting the Emperor in Western India, his memorials and responses met with imperial approval. On their return to *Yunzhong*, the Perfected learned of unrest in the eastern mountains and the southward advance of the imperial army. He declared: "The lives of the people there hang by a thread. None but you can save them." Thus, he was dispatched to offer pacification and comfort. Those who heard him rejoiced and submitted, and many lives were spared.

In the *yiyou* year, he persuaded the Perfected *Changchun* to reside at the *Taiji* Palace, which is today’s *Changchun* Palace. Though the Master remained in his subordinate’s seat, scholars from all directions gathered like clouds to honor him. The Master said: "I have no merit or virtue—how dare I accept such offerings?" He then withdrew to the *Longyang* Abbey in *Dexing*. The Perfected *Changchun* repeatedly expressed his trust in him through personal letters. When the Perfected ascended, the Master had already retreated to the *Yanxia* Abbey, intending to vanish into seclusion. But the community, pleading for him to assume leadership, reluctantly persuaded him to return to *Changchun* Palace. Taking up the succession, his followers multiplied like spokes converging at a hub, and those bearing tribute and offerings filled the halls daily.

One day, he told his disciples: "I have long been burdened by worldly affairs and yearn for the mountains and forests." Thus, when invited to preside over the rites at *Pingle*, he slipped away to *Jingzhou* and then to the eastern mountains. Before long, the officials and scholars of *Yanjing* urgently entreated him to return to the palace. In the *renchen* year, as the Emperor returned from his southern campaign, the Master greeted him at *Shuntian*. The Emperor received him with great warmth and had the Empress personally offer incense at *Changchun* Palace, bestowing generous rewards.

In the spring of the *jiawu* year, he traveled to *Mujian* Mountain. *Li Xuxuan* of the *Taixuan* Abbey remarked to others: "Last year, a mist of blue *qi* lingered over our abbey for days. The diviners said an extraordinary person would arrive—and now the Master has come, proving their words true." In the late spring, as he journeyed south, he reached *Yutian*, where the people rejoiced and urged him to stay for several days. As dusk fell, he suddenly hastened his carriage, traveling over fifty *li* through the night before resting in a field of tall grass. His followers did not understand why. Only later, upon returning to the palace, did they learn that at *Yutian*, hundreds of bandits had planned to raid them. The bandits pursued them to *Dahedian* but turned back, unable to catch up. His disciples congratulated one another, saying: "Without the Master, what would have become of us?" At that time, the Empress sent envoys to express her concern, bestowing a complete collection of Daoist scriptures.

In the spring of the *yiwei* year, he traveled to *Qinzhou* to preside over the *Huanglu* rites. As he entered *Jiaocheng*, some locals dreamed that the local earth deity said: "The Perfected One is coming—guard and protect him from harm." When he conducted the rites in *Pingyao*, the land had suffered prolonged drought and wind. Yet for three days and nights, the lamps and candles burned undisturbed, while elsewhere the winds still raged. *Du Dekang*, the commander of *Qinzhou*, and *Liang Yu*, the commander of *Pingyao*, each donated land for abbeys, and the entire region devoted itself to him.

In the ninth month, he arrived in *Pingyang* and ordered *Song* of *Piyun* to lead the carving of the *Daoist Canon* printing blocks. Within a few years, the project was completed at great expense, yet the people willingly contributed, for the Master had laid the foundation. Seeing the Dao’s teachings flourish, he attributed the success to the founding master, the Perfected *Chongyang*, and turned his attention to the ancestral abbey.

At that time, *Tian*, the provincial governor of *Jingzhao*, sent an urgent memorial to invite him. Coincidentally, this aligned with the Master’s own wishes. In the spring of the *bingshen* year, he arrived. Amid the overgrown wilderness, he surveyed and marked the burial grounds and the foundations for abbeys. The abbeys of *Zhongnan*, *Taihua*, and other sites, long abandoned and beyond restoration, all requested him to take charge. As *Shanxi* had only recently been pacified, some survivors still held out in fortified strongholds. Upon hearing of the Master’s arrival, they surrendered one after another. He comforted and reassured them, and all returned to their homes in peace.

Later, he was summoned to *Yunzhong* and tasked with selecting the most disciplined and virtuous Daoists from across the land to pray for the nation’s blessings and guide the people toward goodness. At that time, the *Xingguo* Abbey in *Pingbi*, *Shenqing* of *Dun*, the *Yuxu Baiyun* Grotto of *Qian’gao*, the *Chongyang* Abbey in *Dingxiang*, the *Shenxiao* Abbey in *Ji*, and the *Xuandu* Abbey in *Pingyang* were all placed under his care.

In the autumn, the Emperor ordered *Yang*, the Minister of the Secretariat, to summon him back to *Yanjing*. Passing through the *Taihang* Mountains, bandits knelt in submission and received his teachings, all becoming law-abiding citizens. As he traveled through *Jingxing*, then *Zhao*, *Wei*, *Qi*, and *Lu*, those seeking his guidance were politely turned away. Yet along the roads and in the fields, people set out incense and flowers, bowing in welcome as he passed. The number of those who came to pay their respects daily reached into the tens of thousands, and the gifts piled up like mountains, though he paid them no heed.

In the spring of the *wuxu* year, he suddenly declared: "I am old and weary of worldly affairs." On the first day of the first month, he passed his robe and alms bowl to the Perfected *Changchang* Li, entrusting him with the leadership of the teachings. He then chose to build a retreat on *Wuhua* Mountain and renovated the *Zhenyang* Abbey on *Dafang* Mountain, renaming it *Qinghe* Palace, intending it as his place of retirement.

The burial preparations at the ancestral abbey on *Zhongnan* were already complete. In the winter of the *gengzi* year, he was invited to oversee the project. He went gladly, undeterred by the bitter cold or treacherous paths, saying: "This is but a small repayment of my debt to my master." That winter, *Jingzhao* suffered from drought. The people prayed, saying: "The Master’s arrival will bring harmony—snow will fall as soon as he arrives." And indeed, as he disembarked, snow began to fall. The grand burial rites were held on the twenty-fifth day of the first month of the following year.

Though *Shanxi* had only recently been pacified and remained a critical border region, those who gathered for the funeral—Daoists and laypeople from all directions—numbered in the tens of thousands. Rumors swirled, and unrest loomed. Yet owing to the Master’s long-standing virtue and moral authority, he quelled all disturbances, ensuring the rites were completed without incident.

In the *jimao* year, the *Taizu Emperor* dispatched *Liu Zhonglu*, acting on imperial authority, to summon the Perfected *Changchun*...

chunks.original_text: 初，重阳真人修道於此，既成，火其庵而束，贻诗有后人复修意，至是师赓之，亦有继祖来修之语。 噫，百年事终始胳合，岂偶然哉。 於是剪芜平丘，土木并作，堂麻殿阁集然一新。 既成，额以重阳，以示报本意。 若华山之云台、骊山之华清、太平宗圣等宫，悉择名重耆宿以主之，兴完皆瑜旧。 是年还燕，夏五月过太原，时自春不雨禾种不入，师怜之，出己帑物为香火费，为民祈梼，雨大需。 及还燕无几何，谓侍者曰：我常便清和宫之西堂，故居之，今为我洒扫方丈。 从之，翌日长往，及官洮类礼圣毕，诀众曰：吾将逝矣。 众惊愕，师曰：吾意已决，夫复何言。 有进纸笔者，默不应。 惟戒葬事勿丰，遂不食，但饮水啜茶，危坐谈道，语音雄畅异常。 是夜久正衣冠，曲肱而逝。 众毁哭过哀，时馨香之气满室，远近闻者奔走赙赠，一辰戚若丧考妣。 初，师遗言葬大房，至是僚士固请，遂葬五华，徇舆意也。 中统改元二年．’诏赠清和妙道广化真人。 师平日着述甚多，门人板之，目曰《葆光集》，并《语录》皆通贯经艺，洞见道体，所谓博学而约说者。 当时朝旨褒崇，及宏儒名卿诗文赞美，裒为一集，目曰《应绿录》．o其觉后进则高下不遗，蹊径坦明，以谦逊勤约为治心之要，以践履功行为入道之基，及其纵说，则时亦露机缄之妙，所谓穷理尽性以至命者也。 得其门者，由堂及奥，其次不失为诚谨之士，其成就於人者如此。 初居潍阳龙虎家，余二十年，姬侍日满前，终莫一识其面。 尝失善马，获其盗，物色既验，盗畏罪不承，曰此我马也。 师即还马纵去，其高洁不累於物如此。 至大至刚之气，充诸内，形诸外，望之如神，即之如春，不怒而威，匪爵而尊，虽万乘不足加其重，虽穷处不足为之轻，其平日之所养者如此。 及遭时得君，权道济物，祥风时雨，覆及远方，歧行喙息，罔不得其所，其见於功用者如此。 其至诚前知，感通神明，则又时出人意表。 以天挺之姿，承积累之基，譬犹日中之阳，月盈之光，不期盛而自盛，尚且谦抑自居，淡泊自乐，化应乎无穷之绿，神寂乎寥廓之乡，体用兼备，无过不及之弊，其诸异乎同源而异流者欤？ 抑世有以纲常为言者，是又大不然。 自四海横溃，华礼荡灭，污俗所染，又岂特於借锄德色，取篇谇语，八佾舞庭，召王所狩者乎？ 及风化所过，暴者仁，夺者让，泰者抑，上下占然，此於纲常之助，其功岂易量哉。 仆悼夫昧大体而妄自分裂者，故并及之。 铭曰： 叔世运厄坤轴旋，皇纲解纽兵方连。 鼎中生灵若小鲜，磨牙万喙垂饥涎。 天生至人盖汝怜，神道设教界己专。 重阳发源亦有传，得自无始先天先。 世问果有甘河泉，万劫老振常涓涓。 琉入潍阳玉清前，灌溉六叶开金莲。 混沌虽凿大道全，积霭扫尽孤月圆。 至理浑融无正偏，漆园郑圃非独贤。 遭时得君明机权，鉴光亦岂从娃妍。 冥鸿高举蓬海边，间阖万里来翩翩。 鳖头可钓虎可编，万蚪谁信容笞鞭。 颓彼力障回九川，涂炭气化成几筵。 惠雨一洒劫火燃，大地垦作种玉田。 精卫投石海空填，螟蛉遇祝速变迁。 风云千载非偶然，转祸为福皆夤绿。 归来演教谈妙玄，英华咀嚼九九篇。 琅函万轴成蹄荃，始信天上无痴仙。
chunks.translated_text:
At the outset, True Man Chongyang had cultivated the Dao here, and upon its completion, he burned his thatched hut and departed, leaving behind a poem with the intent that later generations would restore it. Now, the Master fulfilled this wish, echoing the words of those who would follow the ancestral path to continue the work. Ah! The beginning and end of a century’s affairs intertwined so perfectly—how could this be mere coincidence? Thereupon, he cleared the overgrowth and leveled the mounds, and construction began in earnest: halls, porches, pavilions, and towers all rose anew. Once completed, he named it *Chongyang*, to signify his repayment of the foundational debt. Other temples—such as *Yuntai* on Mount Hua, *Huaqing* on Mount Li, and *Zongsheng* in Taiping—were each entrusted to venerable elders of great renown, their restoration and renewal surpassing their former glory.

That year, as he returned to Yan, he passed through Taiyuan in the fifth month of summer. Since spring, no rain had fallen, and the fields lay unsown. Moved by compassion, the Master took from his own treasury to fund incense and offerings, praying on behalf of the people. A great rain then poured down. Soon after his return to Yan, he said to his attendants: "I have long favored the western hall of *Qinghe Palace* as my dwelling. Prepare it for me now." They complied. The following day, he departed this life. After the rites for the *Washing of the Buddha* were completed, he took leave of the assembly, saying: "I am about to pass away." The crowd was stunned. The Master said: "My resolve is firm—what more is there to say?" When someone offered paper and brush, he remained silent. He only instructed that his burial should not be lavish. Then he ceased eating, drinking only water and tea, sitting upright as he discoursed on the Dao, his voice resonant and unnaturally strong.

That night, he adjusted his robes and cap, folded his arm beneath his head, and passed away. The mourners wailed in grief beyond measure. A fragrant aroma filled the chamber, and those who heard of it from afar hastened to offer condolences and gifts, their sorrow as profound as if they had lost their own parents. Initially, the Master had wished to be buried at *Dafang*, but his officials and disciples pleaded otherwise, and so he was interred at *Wuhua*, yielding to their wishes. In the second year of the *Zhongtong* reign, an imperial edict posthumously bestowed upon him the title *True Man of Pure Harmony, Wondrous Dao, and Vast Transformation*.

The Master’s writings were prolific. His disciples compiled them into a collection titled *Baoguang Ji*, along with his *Recorded Sayings*, both of which thoroughly expounded the classics and revealed the essence of the Dao—embodying the ideal of broad learning distilled into concise discourse. At the time, imperial decrees lauded his virtues, and eminent officials and scholars composed poems and essays in his praise, later gathered into a volume titled *Yinglü Lu*. In guiding his followers, he made no distinctions of high or low, illuminating the path with clarity. He taught that humility, diligence, and restraint were the keys to cultivating the mind, and that practice and action were the foundation of entering the Dao. Yet when he expounded freely, he occasionally revealed the subtleties of the Dao’s hidden mechanisms—what is called "exhausting principle, fulfilling one’s nature, and attaining destiny."

Those who entered his gate progressed from the outer halls to the inner sanctum; even those who did not advance far remained sincere and steadfast. Such was his transformative influence on others. For twenty years, he resided in the *Longhu* household of Weiyang, where concubines and attendants filled his presence daily, yet none ever saw his face. Once, he lost a fine horse, and when the thief was caught, the evidence was irrefutable. Fearing punishment, the thief denied it, insisting, "This is my horse." The Master simply returned the horse and let him go. Such was his loftiness, untouched by worldly entanglements.

His qi, vast and unyielding, filled his being and manifested outwardly. To behold him was to see a divine presence; to approach him was to feel the warmth of spring. Though he never raged, his authority was palpable; though he held no rank, his dignity was innate. Neither the might of an emperor could add to his weight, nor the lowliest station diminish it. Such was the cultivation of his daily life.

When the times aligned and he found favor with the ruler, he wielded the Dao’s power to aid all beings. Like timely winds and seasonable rains, his blessings extended far and wide, ensuring that all creatures—whether crawling or breathing—found their rightful place. Such were the manifestations of his efficacy.

His utmost sincerity and foresight moved the divine, often surpassing human expectations. Endowed by heaven with extraordinary gifts and building upon a foundation of accumulated merit, he was like the sun at its zenith or the moon at its fullness—naturally radiant without striving. Yet he remained humble, content in simplicity, his transformations responding to boundless conditions, his spirit abiding in the vastness of emptiness. His essence and function were perfectly balanced, free from excess or deficiency. Was he not one of those who, though sharing the same source, flowed in different streams?

Some may argue that the Master neglected the cardinal principles of human relations. This is far from the truth. Since the realm had fallen into chaos and the rites of Hua had collapsed, the corruption of customs ran deep—how could it be limited to mere displays of virtue, empty words, or the spectacle of *Eight Rows of Dancers* in the palace, or the imperial hunt? Yet where his transformative influence passed, the violent became benevolent, the greedy became yielding, the arrogant became restrained. Order was restored between high and low. In upholding the cardinal principles, his merit was beyond measure.

I lament those who, blind to the greater whole, recklessly divide and fragment. Thus, I have addressed this as well.

**Inscription:**
In an age of decline, the axis of earth turned awry,
The royal net unraveled, and wars raged on.
The people, like minnows in a cauldron,
Were ground between the jaws of a thousand hungry beasts.

Heaven, in its compassion, sent a perfected one,
Whose divine teachings set boundaries and took charge.
The lineage of Chongyang has its origins,
Tracing back to the primordial, before heaven and earth.

Was there truly a *Ganhe* spring in the world?
After ten thousand kalpas, its flow remains unceasing.
It flowed into Weiyang, before the *Jade Clarity* temple,
Nourishing six generations to bloom like golden lotuses.

Though the chaos was pierced, the great Dao remained whole,
The accumulated haze swept away, leaving the solitary moon full.
The supreme principle is all-embracing, neither biased nor partial—
Not even the masters of *Qi Yuan* or *Zheng Pu* could claim exclusivity.

Meeting the times and gaining the ruler’s favor, he wielded subtle power,
His discernment not swayed by mere beauty or charm.
Like a soaring wild swan at the edge of the Peng Sea,
He traversed the gates of heaven, covering ten thousand miles in flight.

Who would believe that turtles could be hooked or tigers tamed,
That myriad creatures would submit to his staff?
He dredged the nine rivers, turning desolation into abundance,
Transforming the scorched earth into fields of jade.

Like the *Jingwei* bird filling the sea with stones,
Or the *Mingling* larva swiftly transformed by prayer,
The winds and clouds of a thousand years were no accident—
Turning misfortune to blessing, all through hidden connections.

Returning, he expounded the teachings and discoursed on the wondrous mystery,
His words savored like the *Nine-Nine* classic.
Scrolls of jade-like texts filled ten thousand volumes,
Proving at last that heaven holds no foolish immortals.

chunks.original_text: 沬泗岂特徒三千，灯分大小俱婵婵。 有心不敢自圣癫，有口难说无碍禅。 人云功行褊八涎，波浪幻迹从佃佃。 草楼菟裘茅一橡，茹芝大房腹便便。 直钩坐钓三峰巅，宝地花木肥芋芋。 青山不碍行云烟，死而不亡寿更延。 他山有瑛实可铸，光腾亿劫无岁年。 千溪万壑分婵娟，明月依旧悬青天。 玄门掌教大宗师真常真人道行碑铭 翰林学士承匕曰资善大夫知制诰兼修国史王鹊撰 道教之曰全真，以重阳真人为祖师，其自甘河仙遇，刘蒋焚庵，行化关东，前后仅十年，而天下翕然宗之，非信道笃而自知明，安能特立章章如是？ 卒之搜奇访逸，得高第四人，曰丹阳、曰长真、曰长生、曰长春。 四人者，俱能整玄纲，弘圣教，使运数起而道德新，逮矣哉。 至於礼聘两国，声驰四方，生能无欲，殁能不坏，惟长春师为然。 师救物以仁，度人以慈，澹然无极，而众美从之，故游其门者率聪明特达之士。 然传法嗣教止於尹清和、李真常二公而已。 清和公早慕真风，褊趋法席，潍阳化度，沙漠侍行，为长春门弟子之冠。 其踵师掌教，谦抑不居，竟脱烦劳，优游以寿终。 若夫以清静养真，以仁恕接物，华实相副，文质兼全，名重望崇，使远近道俗趋拜堂下，惟恐其后，则吾真常公有之矣。 公讳志常，字浩然，其先洛州永年人，宋季避地濮之范阳，寻又徙开之观城，因着籍焉。 高祖皓、曾祖昌、祖明、父蔓，皆隐德不耀，素为乡里所重。 明昌癸丑春正月十有九日，母聂氏夜梦异服一人授以玉儿，觉而生公。 二岁丧父，六岁丧母，养於伯父济川家。 济川讳蒙，名举子也。 赋义两科，屡占上游，虽以四举终场同进士出身，歉如也。 见公颖悟不群，崭然出头角，意欲作成，以偿平昔之愿，而公不喜文饬，雅好恬澹，常默祷高穹，望早逢异师胜友，式副夙心。 年十有九，伯将议婚，公闻之叹曰：本期学道，未涉津涯，若爱欲缠缚，则古人高蹈出尘之事业难乎有成矣。 同舍兄张本敏之初以嗣续规公，既知牢不可夺，乃各言所志而诀。 居无几，负书曳杖，作云水之游，初隐东莱之牢山，复徙天柱山之仙人宫。 宫之主者日汤阴李仙，见公仪观魁伟，音吐不凡，大加赏异。 逮公辞，告之曰：君玄门大器也，山庵荒僻，非久淹之地。 昔祖师所至，异人并出，今独长春在焉，宜往从之。 他时成就，未可量也。 公翌日遂行，至即墨之东山。 属贞佑丧乱，土寇蜂起，山有窟室，可容数百人，寇至则避其中。 众以公后，拒而不纳。 俄为寇所获，问窟所在，捶楚惨毒，绝而复苏，竟不以告。 寇退，窟入者出，环泣而谢之曰：吾侪小人，数百口之命，悬於公一言，而公能忘不纳之怨，以死救之，其过常情远甚。 争为给养，至於康调，迄今父老犹能道之。 岁戊寅夏六月，闻长春师自登居莱，公促装往拜席下。 师一见器许，待之异常。 山东路转运使田琢器之，高其行，且闻昔在即墨，主帅黄掴副统咨公筹画，保完一城，以书邀至益都，待以宾礼。 己卯冬十有二月，我朝遣便宜刘相仲禄资诏备礼，起长春师于东莱。 时益都副帅张林自金归宋，叛服靡常，公惧其为阻滞，乃往说林，俾移檄所驾，卫送以行。 庚辰春正月，师始命经，从行者十有八人，公其一也。
chunks.translated_text:
At the Wei and Si Rivers, were there merely three thousand disciples?
The lamps, great and small, all shone with radiant clarity.

With a heart, one dared not claim madness as sanctity;
With a mouth, one could scarcely speak of the unimpeded Chan.
Some said his merit and conduct were narrow as the Eight Delusions,
Yet his waves and illusions followed the humble and unassuming.

His thatched hut was but a single beam, a rustic retreat,
Where he ate the *lingzhi* and *taifang* mushrooms, his belly full.
With a straight hook he sat fishing atop the three peaks,
Where the sacred land’s flowers and trees flourished lush and green.

Green mountains did not hinder the drifting clouds,
And though dead, he was not lost—his longevity ever extended.
On other mountains lay jade-like ore, truly fit for forging,
Its light shining through a hundred million kalpas, ageless and timeless.

A thousand streams and ten thousand valleys divided the beauty,
Yet the bright moon still hung in the blue heavens above.

*The Stele Inscription for the Daoist Virtues of the Grand Master and True Perpetual Realized One, Who Presides Over the Mysterious Gate’s Teachings*

Composed by Wang Que, Hanlin Academician, *Chengyi* Grand Master, Participant in the Drafting of Edicts, and Compiler of the National History

The Daoist school is called Quanzhen, with True Man Chongyang as its patriarch. From his immortal encounter at Gan River, the burning of his hut by Liu and Jiang, to his proselytizing in Guandong, barely a decade passed before the world unanimously revered him. Had he not been steadfast in the Dao and clear in self-knowledge, how could he have established such a resplendent legacy?

In the end, he sought out the extraordinary and visited the reclusive, gathering four eminent disciples: Danyang, Changzhen, Changsheng, and Changchun. These four were all capable of rectifying the mysterious principles and propagating the sagely teachings, renewing the Dao and virtue as the times demanded. How far-reaching was their influence!

As for extending invitations to two nations and making his name resound across the four directions, living without desire and perishing without decay—only Master Changchun achieved this. He saved beings with benevolence, delivered people with compassion, and in his serene boundlessness, all virtues followed him. Thus, those who entered his gate were invariably men of keen intelligence and exceptional talent. Yet his transmission of the Dharma and succession of the teachings ended solely with two masters: Yin Qinghe and Li Zhenchang.

Master Qinghe had early admired the true wind, hastening to the Dharma seat. In Weiyang, he transformed and delivered beings; in the desert, he attended his master’s journey, becoming the foremost disciple of Changchun’s gate. When he succeeded his master in presiding over the teachings, he remained humble and unassuming, ultimately shedding worldly toils to pass away in leisurely longevity.

As for one who nurtured the true with tranquility, treated others with benevolence and forbearance, matched outward elegance with inner substance, and combined refinement with sincerity—whose name was weighty and reputation lofty, drawing Daoists and laypeople near and far to prostrate at his hall, fearing only to lag behind—such was our True Perpetual Master.

The Master’s name was Zhichang, styled Haoran. His ancestors hailed from Yongnian in Luozhou. At the end of the Song, they fled to Fanyang in Pu, then later moved to Guancheng in Kai, where they settled and registered. His great-grandfather Hao, grandfather Chang, father Ming, and father Man all concealed their virtue without ostentation, yet were deeply respected by their village.

In the spring of the *guichou* year of the Mingchang era (1193), on the nineteenth day of the first month, his mother, née Nie, dreamed of a strangely attired man presenting her with a jade child. Upon waking, she gave birth to the Master. At two, he lost his father; at six, his mother. He was raised in the household of his uncle Jichuan.

Jichuan, whose name was Meng, was a renowned scholar. Excelling in both poetry and prose, he repeatedly ranked at the top, though despite four attempts at the metropolitan examination, he attained only the status of a *tong jinshi chushen*, leaving him somewhat unsatisfied. Seeing the Master’s exceptional intelligence and outstanding talent, he intended to cultivate him to fulfill his long-held aspirations. Yet the Master disliked literary refinement, favoring instead a life of tranquility. He often silently prayed to the high heavens, hoping to early encounter an extraordinary teacher or worthy friend to fulfill his lifelong aspirations.

At nineteen, his uncle began arranging his marriage. The Master sighed upon hearing this: “I originally aspired to study the Dao, yet I have not even touched its shores. If I become entangled in love and desire, how could I ever achieve the lofty, transcendent endeavors of the ancients?” His fellow student, Zhang Benmin, initially urged him to continue the family line, but upon realizing his resolve was unshakable, they each declared their aspirations and parted ways.

Soon after, he packed his books and staff, embarking on a wandering journey. First, he secluded himself on Laoshan in Donglai, then later moved to the Immortal’s Palace on Mount Tianzhu. The master of the palace, Li Xian of Tangyin, was struck by the Master’s imposing bearing and extraordinary speech, greatly admiring him. When the Master prepared to leave, Li said to him: “You are a vessel of great capacity for the Mysterious Gate. This mountain hermitage is remote and desolate—no place for a prolonged stay. In the past, wherever the Patriarch traveled, extraordinary individuals emerged. Now, only Changchun remains. You should go and follow him. Your future accomplishments cannot be foretold.”

The next day, the Master set out and arrived at Dongshan in Jimo. At the time, the *zhenyou* era (1213–1217) was marked by chaos, with bandits swarming like bees. The mountain had caves that could shelter hundreds. When bandits approached, the people hid inside, but they barred the Master from entering, refusing him. Soon after, he was captured by the bandits, who demanded to know the cave’s location. They tortured him cruelly, and though he fainted, he revived without revealing it. When the bandits withdrew, those who had hidden in the cave emerged, surrounding him in tears to express their gratitude: “We are but petty men. The lives of hundreds depended on your single word, yet you forgot the grievance of being barred and saved us at the cost of your life. Your virtue far surpasses ordinary human sentiment.” They competed to provide for him until he recovered. Even today, the elders still speak of this.

In the summer of the *wuyin* year (1218), the Master heard that Master Changchun had moved from Deng to Lai. He hurriedly prepared and went to pay homage at his seat. The Master was immediately recognized and treated with exceptional favor. Tian Zhuo, the Transport Commissioner of Shandong, esteemed his conduct and, having heard of his past service in Jimo—where General Huang Guo consulted him on strategy to preserve the city—invited him to Yidu with a letter, treating him as an honored guest.

In the winter of the *jimao* year (1219), our dynasty dispatched the plenipotentiary Liu Zhonglu, bearing an edict and gifts, to summon Master Changchun from Donglai. At the time, Zhang Lin, the deputy commander of Yidu, had defected from Jin to Song, his allegiance shifting unpredictably. Fearing he might obstruct the journey, the Master went to persuade Lin to issue a proclamation escorting the imperial carriage, ensuring safe passage. In the spring of the *gengchen* year (1220), the Master finally received the command to depart. Among the eighteen who accompanied him, the Master was one.

Proving at last that heaven holds no foolish immortals.

chunks.original_text: 二月达燕，明年春二月北上，秋七月至阿不罕山，距汉地几万里，并山汉人千家逆师罗拜，以为希世之遇，咸请立观择人主之。 师将行，指公坐上语众曰：此子通明中正，学问该洽，今为汝等留此，其善待之。 因赐公真常子号，额名其观日栖霞。 师既西迈，公率众兴作，刻日落成，又立长春、玉华二会，至今不报。 癸未夏五月，师至自行在，憩于其观。 一日斋客四集，师手持一弓弦，不言以授公，公亦不言而受，圈而佩之，仍作诗为谢，师但笑领而已。 盖阿不罕之留，弓弦之授，识者知其有付属之意。 秋七月从师还，至下水时，残暑尚炽，师因纳冻官舍之门楼，字呼公而教之曰：真师不易遇，得道者不易逢，逢之而不易识也。 守道之笃，人貌而天，行直寓六骸而渊宗，忘饥渴而常宁，至静而遗形，独游乎无极之妙庭。 此语汝当记之，以俟他日自得之耳。 公拜而谢，自承教之后，益自奋励，息机体真，敬事循理，历死生忧患之际，曾不易其所守。 师住燕京之日，凡教门公事必与闻之。 丁亥秋七月，师既仙去，清和嗣教，以公为都道录兼领长春宫事。 己丑秋七月，见上於乾楼辈，时方诏通经之士教太子，公进《易》、《诗书》、《道德》、《孝经》，且具陈大义，上嘉之。 冬十一月，得旨方还。 庚寅冬，有诬告处顺堂绘事有不应者，清和即日被执，众皆骇散，公独请代之曰：清和宗师也，职在传道。 教门一切，我悉主之，罪则在我，他人无及焉。 使者高其节，特兔扭械，锁之入狱。 夜半锁忽自开，公以语狱吏，吏复锁之，而复自开。 平日一吏以白有司，适以来使会食，所食肉骨上隐然见师像，其讼遂息。 癸巳夏六月，承诏即燕京，教蒙古贵官之子十有八人，公荐寂照大师冯志亨佐其事，日就月将，而才艺有可称者。 乙未秋七月，奉诏筑道院於和林，委公选高道乘传以来。 虽清和掌教，而朝观往来必以公，故公为朝廷所知，而数数得旨，玺书所称曰：仙孔八合识。 八合识译语师也。 戊戌春正月，清和会四方耆旧，手自为书付公，俾嗣教。 公度不能辞乃受之。 三月，大行台断事官忽土虎奉朝命复加玄门正派嗣法演教真常真人号。 夏四月赴阙，以教门事条奏，首及终南山灵虚观，系重阳祖师炼真开化之地，得旨赐重阳宫号，命大为营建。 甲辰春正月，朝命令公於长春宫作普天大醮三千六百分位，及选行业精严之士，普赐戒录。 逮戊申春二月既望，醮始告成，凡七昼夜，祥应不可婵纪。 岁辛亥，先帝即位之始年也，欲遵祀典遍祭岳读。 冬十月，遣中使诏公至阙下，上端拱御榻，亲缄信香，冥心注想，默梼於祀所者久之，金盒锦磨，皆手授公，选近侍哈力丹为辅行，仍赐内府白金五千两以充其费。 陛辞之日，锡公金符，及倚付玺书，令掌教如故。 公至祭所，设金录醮三昼夜，承制赐登坛道众紫衣，暨所属官吏预醮者，赏责有差。 询问穷乏，量加赈恤。 自恒而岱，岱而衡，衡隶宋境，公尝奏可於天坛望杞焉。 既又合祭四读於济源，终之至於嵩，至於华，皆如怛岱之礼。 祀所多有征应，鸿儒巨笔，碑以纪之。 壬子春正月，命驾终南祖庭，恭行祀礼，规度营造，凡山下道院皆为一例，以是地系教门根本故也。
chunks.translated_text:
In the second month, they reached Yan. The following spring, in the second month, they journeyed northward, and by the seventh month of autumn, they arrived at Mount Abu Khan, nearly ten thousand *li* from Han territory. Along the mountain, a thousand Han households came forth to greet the Master, prostrating in rows, regarding the encounter as a rare opportunity. All entreated him to establish an abbey and select a successor to preside over it.

As the Master prepared to depart, he pointed to the Master [hereafter referred to as "the subject"] among those seated and addressed the assembly: "This one is enlightened, upright, and learned, his knowledge comprehensive. I shall leave him here for you; treat him well." Thereupon, he bestowed upon the subject the Daoist name *Zhenchangzi* and named the abbey *Qixia* ("Resting Clouds"). After the Master had set forth westward, the subject led the assembly in construction, completing the abbey in a matter of days. He also established the *Changchun* and *Yuhua* societies, which remain active to this day.

In the summer of the *guiwei* year (1223), the fifth month, the Master returned from his travels and rested at the abbey. One day, as guests gathered for a vegetarian feast, the Master silently handed the subject a bowstring; the subject, likewise silent, accepted it, coiled it, and wore it at his waist. He then composed a poem in gratitude, to which the Master merely smiled in acknowledgment. Those with discernment understood that the Master’s decision to leave him at Abu Khan and the gift of the bowstring signified an intent to entrust him with succession.

In the seventh month of autumn, the subject accompanied the Master on his return journey. When they reached the Xia River, the lingering heat was still intense. The Master took shelter in the gate tower of an official residence, called the subject by name, and instructed him: "A true master is not easily encountered; one who has attained the Dao is not easily met. Even when met, he is not easily recognized. Those who steadfastly uphold the Dao appear human in form but embody the celestial; their conduct is upright, their essence profound, abiding in the six senses yet rooted in the abyss. They forget hunger and thirst, ever at peace, utterly still, transcending form, and wander alone in the wondrous court of the boundless. Remember these words, and await the day you comprehend them for yourself."

The subject bowed in gratitude. From that moment on, he redoubled his efforts, quieting his mind to embody the true, reverently attending to affairs with principle. Through life and death, through hardship and peril, he never wavered in his resolve.

During the Master’s stay in Yanjing, the subject was privy to all matters concerning the teaching. In the seventh month of autumn in the *dinghai* year (1227), after the Master had ascended to immortality, Qinghe succeeded to the teaching and appointed the subject as *Dudao Lu* (Director of Daoist Affairs), concurrently overseeing the affairs of Changchun Abbey.

In the seventh month of autumn in the *jichou* year (1229), the subject was received by the Emperor at Qianlou Pavilion. At the time, the court had issued an edict summoning scholars well-versed in the classics to instruct the crown prince. The subject presented the *Book of Changes*, the *Book of Songs*, the *Book of Documents*, the *Dao De Jing*, and the *Classic of Filial Piety*, expounding their essential meanings. The Emperor praised him and, in the eleventh month of winter, granted him leave to return.

In the winter of the *gengyin* year (1230), false accusations arose regarding the paintings in Chushun Hall, alleging impropriety. Qinghe was immediately arrested, and the assembly scattered in alarm. The subject alone stepped forward to take his place, declaring: "Qinghe is the lineage master, charged with transmitting the Dao. All matters of the teaching are my responsibility; if there is guilt, it is mine alone, and no other shall bear it." The emissary, admiring his integrity, exempted him from restraints and shackles, though he was still imprisoned. At midnight, the shackles suddenly fell open. The subject informed the jailer, who reattached them, only for them to open again. A jailer reported this to the authorities, and by coincidence, a foreign envoy was dining with them. On the bone of the meat they were eating, the Master’s likeness appeared faintly, and the dispute was thereby resolved.

In the sixth month of summer in the *guisi* year (1233), the subject received an edict to instruct eighteen sons of Mongol nobles in Yanjing. He recommended the Venerable Master Jizhao, Feng Zhiheng, to assist in the endeavor. Day by day, month by month, their talents and skills flourished, earning praise.

In the seventh month of autumn in the *yiwei* year (1235), the subject was ordered to construct a Daoist abbey in Helin. He was entrusted with selecting eminent Daoists to travel there by post carriage. Though Qinghe presided over the teaching, the subject was invariably summoned for audiences and court visits, earning the favor of the throne. He frequently received edicts, and the imperial decrees addressed him as *Xian Kong Bahe Shi* ("Master of the Eightfold Understanding"), *Bahe Shi* being the translated title for "master."

In the first month of spring in the *wuxu* year (1238), Qinghe convened elders from all directions and personally inscribed a document entrusting the subject with succession. Judging that refusal was impossible, the subject accepted. In the third month, the *Duan Shiguan* (Chief Justice of the Grand Court of Appeals) Hutu Hu, acting on imperial command, bestowed upon him the title *Xuanzheng Zhipai Sifa Yanjiao Zhenchang Zhenren* ("Perfected One of True Constancy, Successor of the Orthodox Lineage, Transmitter of the Dao and Teaching").

In the fourth month of summer, the subject journeyed to the capital and memorialized the throne on matters concerning the teaching. He first addressed Lingxu Abbey on Mount Zhongnan, the site where Ancestral Master Chongyang had cultivated the true and initiated the teaching. The Emperor issued an edict bestowing the name *Chongyang Abbey* and ordered its grand reconstruction.

In the first month of spring in the *jiachen* year (1244), the court commanded the subject to conduct a *Putian Dajiao* ("Great Offering for All Under Heaven") at Changchun Abbey, comprising 3,600 altars, and to select practitioners of strict discipline, universally bestowing upon them precepts and registers. By the fifteenth day of the second month in spring of the *wushen* year (1248), the ritual was completed, spanning seven days and nights. Auspicious signs manifested beyond enumeration.

In the *xinhai* year (1251), the first year of the late Emperor’s reign, he desired to observe the rites of sacrifice, offering to the mountains and rivers. In the tenth month of winter, he dispatched an emissary to summon the subject to the capital. The Emperor sat upright upon his throne, personally sealing incense and silently concentrating his thoughts in prayer at the sacrificial site for a long while. He then handed the subject a golden casket and brocade pouch, selecting the attendant Halidan to assist in the journey. He further bestowed 5,000 *liang* of silver from the imperial treasury to cover expenses.

On the day of his departure, the Emperor conferred upon the subject a golden tally and an imperial decree, entrusting him with the oversight of the teaching as before. Upon reaching the sacrificial site, the subject conducted a *Jinlu Jiao* ("Golden Register Offering") for three days and nights. By imperial decree, he bestowed purple robes upon the Daoist assembly who ascended the altar, and rewards were distributed to the officials and subordinates who participated in the ritual. He inquired after the destitute and provided relief according to their needs.

From Mount Heng to Mount Tai, and from Mount Tai to Mount Heng, which lay within Song territory, the subject memorialized the throne, proposing to perform the rites from the Altar of Heaven. He then combined the sacrifices to the four rivers at Jiyuan, concluding with Mount Song and Mount Hua, observing the same rites as at Mount Tai. At the sacrificial sites, many responses and signs were witnessed, which eminent scholars recorded in inscriptions.

In the first month of spring in the *renzi* year (1252), the subject journeyed to the ancestral abbey on Mount Zhongnan to reverently perform the rites. He surveyed and planned the construction, standardizing all abbeys at the foot of the mountain, for this was the root of the teaching.

At the time, Zhang Lin, the deputy commander of Yidu, had defected from Jin to Song, his allegiance shifting unpredictably. Fearing he might obstruct the journey, the Master went to persuade Lin to issue a proclamation escorting the imperial carriage, ensuring safe passage. In the spring of the *gengchen* year (1220), the Master finally received the command to depart. Among the eighteen who accompanied him, the Master was one.

chunks.original_text: 逮四月既望束归。 癸丑春正月，奉上命作金录大斋，给散随路道士女冠普度戒牒，以公为印押大宗师。 甲寅春，上又遣使作普天大醮，分位日期，如戊申，而益以附荐海内亡魂，劝公为大济度师，出黄金五百两，白金五千两，凡龙璧环纽镇信之物，及沉檀龙麝诸香，并从官给。 自发牒至满散，鸾鹤五云现於空际者无虚日。 公复念燕境罪徒久幽狸讦，不以湔洗，则无由自新，言之有司，蒙开释者甚众。 冬十有二月，有旨召公，乙卯秋七月，见上於行宫。 适西域进方物，时太子诸王就宴，劲公预焉。 舍馆既定，数召见，咨以治国保民之术。 十有二月朔旦，上谓公曰：朕欲天下百姓安生乐业，然与我同此心者未见其人，何如？ 公奏曰：自古圣君有爱民之心，则才德之士必应诚而至。 因历举勋贤并用，可成国泰民安之效，上嘉纳之，命书诸册。 自午未问入承顾问，及灯乃退，丙辰春正月，以老辞。 夏四月，至自北庭。 五月至晦，总真阁之北檐无故摧坏。 六月庚申朔，公倦於接应，谢绝宾客，隐几不言。 戊寅，正襟危坐，语左右曰：昨夜境界异常，吾自知卦数已尽，归其时矣。 主管教门，向已奏闻，令诚明张志敬受代，余无可议者。 翌日，悉以符印法衣付之，乃留颂，顺正而化，春秋六十有四。 平昔着述多为人所持去，有《又玄集》二十卷、《西游记》二卷行於世。 公以儒家者流次意学道，事师谨，与人忠，茹荤饮酒之戒涓毫不犯。 主宫门二十年，凡所营缮，皆公指授，单飞栉比，雄冠一时。 四方信施，岁入良多，悉付之常住，一无私积，羽化之日衣袅杖屦而已。 、性质直，不能曲意顺情，故谤讼屡兴，随即自解，公一不校，复以诚信待之。 方其与同舍张君敏之之诀也，各言其志，敏之卒中词赋高第，而公竟掌道教长春。 别几二纪，敏之以使北见留，隐为黄冠，公兄事如昔，并其属给养之。 时河南新附，士大夫之流寓於燕者，往往窜名道籍，公委曲招延，饭于斋堂日数十人。 或者驮其烦，公不恤也，其待士之诚类如此。 长春道倡不下数百，独能识诚明於龄稚，教育成就，卒付重任，其知人之明又如此。 故能历事三朝，荐承恩顾，云耕所至，倾动南北，香火送迎，络绎不绝。 及闻讣音，近者素服长号，若丧考妣，远者出近仙灵，为位以哭，可谓其生也荣，其死也哀矣。 庚申夏四月，今上嗣登宝位，中统辛酉秋八月，诏赠真常上德宣教真人号。 明年夏五月既望，予方逃暑不出，诚明子拥诸执事踵门来见，曰：先师嗣法有功玄教，今畎世几七年，不有以追述其美，则门弟子辈俯仰惭作，殆无了期。 惟先生与师邻乡县，熟其为人，敢以斯文请。 予辞之力，不瑜月凡三见临，具状其师之道行，及持虚舟道人李鼎之和所为传，并以见示。 予观其行实平美，略无织芥谲怪之事，乃以予平昔之所见闻，并为次第其先后而铭之。 铭曰： 道之为教，基於老氏，不肆不耀，知足知止。 性而身之，全真则是，质而文之，真常乃尔。 粤惟真常，系出仙李，重阳裔孙，长春嫡子。 笑授弓弦，传法微旨，留建栖霞，嗣教伊始。 言必成章，动必循理，诚以待士，廉以律己。 万口推尊，三朝付倚，善始令终，荣生哀死。 苍苍五华，涓涓一水，窈兮奄麦，闽我冠履。
chunks.translated_text:
Upon returning eastward after the full moon of the fourth month, in the *guichou* year (1253), the first month of spring, he received the imperial command to conduct the Grand Golden Register Retreat. Certificates of universal ordination were distributed to Daoist priests and nuns along the routes, with the subject appointed as the Grand Preceptor to seal and authenticate them.

In the *jiayin* year (1254), spring, the throne once more dispatched envoys to perform the Great Universal Offering. The ranks and schedule followed the precedent of the *wushen* year (1248), with the addition of prayers for the deliverance of departed souls throughout the realm. The subject was urged to serve as the Great Master of Salvation, and five hundred taels of gold, five thousand taels of silver, along with ceremonial objects—dragon jades, rings, seals, and pledges of faith—as well as aloeswood, sandalwood, dragon’s spittle, and musk incense, were all provided by the court. From the issuance of the decree to its fulfillment, auspicious omens of phoenixes, cranes, and five-colored clouds appeared in the skies without fail.

The subject further reflected on the long-imprisoned offenders in the Yan region, who, without absolution, could never renew themselves. He petitioned the authorities, and many were pardoned. In the twelfth month of winter, an imperial summons arrived. In the seventh month of autumn in the *yimao* year (1255), he was received by the emperor at the traveling palace. At that time, tribute from the Western Regions was presented, and the crown prince and various princes held a banquet, to which the subject was invited. Once his lodgings were arranged, he was summoned repeatedly and consulted on the arts of governing the state and protecting the people.

On the first day of the twelfth month, the emperor addressed him: "I wish for all the people under heaven to live in peace and contentment, yet I have not seen anyone who shares this heart with me. What should be done?" The subject memorialized: "Since ancient times, when a sagely ruler cherishes the people, men of talent and virtue inevitably respond to his sincerity. By employing the meritorious and the worthy together, the realm may achieve peace and the people security." The emperor praised and accepted his words, ordering them recorded in the annals. From noon until evening, he received the emperor’s inquiries, retiring only when the lamps were lit.

In the *bingchen* year (1256), the first month of spring, he petitioned to retire due to age. In the fourth month of summer, he returned from the northern court. On the last day of the fifth month, the northern eaves of the Zongzhen Pavilion collapsed without cause. On the first day of the sixth month, the *gengshen* day, weary of receiving visitors, he declined all guests and sat in silence, leaning on his armrest. On the *wuyin* day, he straightened his robes and sat upright, saying to those around him: "Last night, the visions were extraordinary. I know my allotted span is complete, and the time of my return has come. The succession of the teaching has already been memorialized to the throne, with Zhang Zhijing of pure clarity appointed as my successor. There is nothing more to discuss." The following day, he entrusted all talismans, seals, and ritual vestments to him, then composed a final hymn, passed away in proper alignment, at the age of sixty-four.

Many of his writings were taken away by others during his lifetime. Only *The Further Mystery Collection* in twenty fascicles and *The Western Journey Record* in two fascicles remain in circulation. Though born into a Confucian family, he later embraced the Dao, serving his master with reverence and treating others with loyalty. He never violated the precepts against meat or wine, not even in the slightest. For twenty years, he oversaw the abbey gates, directing all construction himself. The structures rose in orderly ranks, unmatched in their grandeur. Offerings from devotees across the land flowed in abundantly each year, yet he dedicated all to the common treasury, keeping nothing for himself. On the day of his ascension, he left behind only his robe, staff, and sandals.

His nature was upright and unbending, unwilling to flatter or conform to others’ whims. Thus, slander and lawsuits arose frequently, though they dissolved on their own. He never took offense, instead treating his detractors with sincerity and trust. When parting from his fellow disciple Zhang Junminzhi, each spoke of his aspirations. Zhang later excelled in poetry and prose, achieving high rank, while the subject ultimately became the leader of the Quanzhen Daoist school. After twenty years apart, Zhang, sent on a mission to the north, was detained and disguised himself as a Daoist priest. The subject treated him as an elder brother, as before, and provided for him and his retinue.

At that time, Henan had recently submitted to the dynasty, and many scholar-officials displaced in Yan had concealed themselves among the Daoist registers. The subject extended invitations to them all, feeding dozens daily in the refectory. Some found the task burdensome, but he paid no heed. Such was his sincerity in treating scholars. Among the hundreds of disciples under Changchun’s teaching, he alone recognized Zhang Zhijing’s sincerity from youth, nurturing and guiding him until entrusting him with great responsibility. Such was his clarity in discerning men.

Thus, he served three reigns, receiving ever-increasing favor and trust. Wherever his carriage traveled, north and south alike were moved. The fragrance of incense and the processions of welcome and farewell never ceased. When news of his passing spread, those nearby donned mourning robes and wailed as if they had lost their parents, while those afar set up altars to his departed spirit and wept before them. Truly, his life was glorious, and his death was mourned.

In the *gengshen* year (1280), the fourth month of summer, the present emperor ascended the throne. In the eighth month of autumn in the *xinyou* year (1281) of the Zhongtong era, he was posthumously honored with the title "Perfected of True Constancy, Propagator of the Daoist Teaching, and Perfected Man." The following year, after the full moon of the fifth month of summer, I was avoiding the heat at home when Zhang Zhijing, accompanied by his attendants, arrived at my door. He said: "Our late master rendered great service in continuing the esoteric teaching. Now, nearly seven years have passed since his departure. Without a record of his virtues, we disciples will forever feel shame when we look back. As you and the master were neighbors in the same region, you knew him well. We humbly request this composition."

I declined repeatedly, but within a month, he visited three times, detailing his master’s conduct and the biography composed by the Daoist Li Ding of the Empty Boat. He presented these to me. Observing his deeds, I found them wholly admirable, free of even the slightest trace of deceit or strangeness. Thus, I have arranged what I have seen and heard of him in order and composed this inscription. The inscription reads:

The Dao as teaching
Traces its roots to Laozi,
Neither extravagant nor ostentatious,
Knowing contentment, knowing cessation.

Nurturing nature in the body,
This is Quanzhen.
Refining the plain with culture,
Thus is True Constancy.

Of True Constancy,
Descended from the immortal Li,
Grandson of Chongyang,
Direct heir of Changchun.

Smiling, he received the bowstring,
Transmitting the subtle essence of the teaching.
Establishing Qixia Abbey,
Marking the beginning of his succession.

His words formed chapters,
His actions followed principle.
Sincere in treating scholars,
Stern in disciplining himself.

Ten thousand mouths extolled him,
Three reigns entrusted him.
Virtuous in beginning and end,
Honored in life, mourned in death.

The azure Five Peaks,
The murmuring stream,
Deep and serene the valley,
Where my cap and sandals rest.
